qas.question: In what city did the standardization of red as a color of stop lights occur?
In what year did nations standardize on red as a color for stop lights?
At what event did the color red become the standard color of stop lights?

answers.text: Vienna Convention on Road Signs and Signals of 1968

qas.question: Red is the color of stoplights due to its universal affiliation with what?
At what time is red at its brightest?

plausible_answers.text: Vienna Convention on Road Signs and Signals

qas.question: What was standardized as the international color at the Vienna Road Signs Convention?
What color next to red is the brightest in the daytime?
What is orange considered during twilight?

context: <b6_0>Red<b6_0/> is the international color of stop signs and stop lights on highways and intersections. It was standarized as the international color at the <a0_0><a2_0><b5_0>Vienna<a0_0/> Convention on Road Signs and Signals<b5_0/> of <a1_0>1968<a2_0/><a1_0/>. It was chosen partly because <b7_0>red<b7_0/> is the brightest color in <a4_0>daytime<a4_0/> (next to orange), though it is less visible at twilight, when green is <b8_0>the most visible color<b8_0/>. Red also stands out more clearly against a cool natural backdrop of blue sky, green trees or gray buildings. But it was mostly chosen as the color for stoplights and stop signs because of its universal association with <a3_0>danger and warning<a3_0/>.
